content:
i also like option2

content: i.e. if we keep it dynamic over the engine api, can't future "difficulty bomb" type upgrades stay limited to the beacon chain?

author: g11tech
content: +1 for option 2 as well, having a client global config updated on every new payload doesn't sound too far reaching to me

author: lightclient
content: in theory, but we aren't even considering them at all. so it seems a classic case of adding complexity to support  a theoretical future use case that we aren't even sure will land

author: robocopsgonemad
content: ok, so put a pin in option2 until all EL clients can handle a wider, more dynamic range of blob targets. till then, option 3.

author: jgm
content: Does it make sense to add the blob info to the fcu message today, even if it is going to be ignored for now? Stops us keep bumping fcu...

author: ryanleeschneider
content: Is including the max blob count in the header really that wasteful?  Aren't RLP values under `0x7f` just stored as a single byte?  Can we restrict the count to a "u7"?

author: lightclient
content: yeah well it depends if we specify max blob count or max blob gas - but sure, i don't think the actual amount of data stored or transmitted is all that problematic. it's more a canary that the design itself is problematic

author: ryanleeschneider
content:
true.  Personally I still prefer explicit (e.g. option 1) just because it feels like with ePBS etc coming at some point there's potentially more places where an implicit number might accidentally get out of sync.  

Or perhaps overkill but what about something like this: we add a new "From CL config" versioned object that is included indirectly in the EL header, so the process is something along the lines of: CL sends `config: { "version": 1, {"data": { max_blob_gas: xxxx }}` and then we include "config_version" as a small int in the EL header?  Lots of hand-waving there just trying to get the gist across succintly w/o getting too deep but the point would be to have a new location to house infrequently changed values like this.  CL-only forks could change existing values while CL/EL combined forks could add new fields.
